title: Missions to win games.

embed.description: Close Ask a question about League or Riot, and we'll try to answer it. Answers go live every Thursday at 1:30 pm (PT) Log in to Ask Riot Thank you for submitting a question! Welcome to Ask Riot! Have a question? Let's talk duo champions, missions, and Noxian tacos.

body:
So in the link above, Riot talks about what kind of missions are successful and what aren't.

it's a good read but long story short:
They think that missions requiring kills/cs/playing-certain-champions etc. are bad and influence people to play differently. 
And that missions that just require people to win, are good, because no one has to go out of their way for that.

But after playing this event for a while, I tend to disagree.

Firstly, when winning games is all you need to do for missions, It kinda defeats the purpose of having a 'mission'. Seeming winning is pretty much the whole point of the game anyway, so regardless of what your mission is, youre always going to be trying to win. 
So rather than striving to complete an objective to gain rewards, you just play normally and rewards just pop up every now and then without you having to do anything. 

Also the problem with having to win games for every mission, is that people can't play all day every day. 
So if they only have time for 2 games, and they lose both of them, then they can't complete the daily missions, and it takes them so much longer to complete the other missions too. 

For example last night my friend and I played for **3 hours** before getting our 10 tickets. And tbh we didn't even want to play anyway, seeming we were already having fun in a different game, but we only did to maximise our ticket gain. A lot of people don't have that kind of time, and so miss out on their missions.

Also, when a mission is "Collect 200 CS" Thats a personal thing that you have control over and can strive towards.
"Win with a Ziggs" isn't. Not only do you have to wait around for there to actually be a Ziggs _(which are not common)_, but then you also have to win the game too. So you have very little control over completing your _personal_ missions.

This is a screenshot of one of my recent games. Myself and a friend were trying to get the _"Win with Ziggs"_ and _"Win with Malz"_ missions, neither of us play either champ _(but we were hardly going to sit and wait for both to just come along)_.

https://i.gyazo.com/251105d157e7d0b193d1b05d001a5fce.png

We lost that game, _(not to be one of **those** guys, but I like to think that we did all we could)_. And so got 0 rewards.
You look at the scores and you think: We could not have tried any harder to win that, and still weren't able to.

It may be different for other people. 
But It doesn't seem right _(for me at least)_ to have missions, that you just have no control over. Either you and your team do well and you win, or you don't and you lose. 
All it is is a 50/50 chance of doing exactly what it is that you're supposed to be doing anyway. It's hardly a 'mission'.

Literally every single mission in this event, requires you to win games.
and it's fun of course, missions are always fun.
But its almost like there it's not even a mission, you just play normally like you would any other day, and occasionally you get an end-game popup saying _"Yayyyyy you've done something"_.

Personally I'm in favour of missions being a little more like you've actually got to go and do something.
If youre really worried about them changing people's playstyle, maybe disable them in ranked or something? So people don't pick champs they wouldn't usually play.

What do people think?
Do you guys prefer win missions or objective missions?

replies.body:
I really can't help but agree with this. With the Arcade event, missions have started to feel less personal and more "grindy", as well as feeling a bit too dependant on other players, when the assumption is that they're meant to be "personal achievements". Whenever I've seen a mission that is simply "Win [X amount of] games", I find myself doing it in Coop, just to get it out the way. At first, I started trying missions through ARURF, but have since reached a point where it just feels more rewarding to play much fewer Coop games, which doesn't seem like it's an intended result of the system.

I suppose one thing to consider is that missions are still in relatively early stages, and Riot are probably just trying out some stuff to see what is and isn't successful. One change I'd like to see is more "objective" oriented missions, such as participating in destroying Towers and Inhibitors, and killing Epic Monsters (Dragon, Baron and Vilemaw), as well as changing "kill/assist" missions to be based on "kill participation" (making them more accessible to each role).

Does Coop vs ai count for wins? I thought they had wised up to that xD
But yea, it does feel like a cop out, probably not what they intended.

I agree, more objective based ones would be great, not only is it something you can also try to do in a losing game, but it makes people more aware of the objectives as well. A double whammy.
Perhaps even 'assassination' missions, like "get takedowns on 10 mages" or something like that. So you're specifically hunting something, and if it is a takedown, it can be kills or assists to cater to both assassin and support players.

But yea, it's just a grind atm.
It's a minimum of 19 wins to complete all the missions. _(52 if they didn't stack)_ + daily missions. Thats a hell of a lot of wins....

It's achievable certainly, but very hard for people who can only manage a game or two a day.

Having played through the arcade missions on two accounts (well, mostly) I can confirm that the only thing that can't be done in Coop is the level 3 Blitz mission, specifically the part about "winning 5 PvP games". It honestly doesn't seem very good that it can be spammed like that in Coop, even with the one part holding me back from completion at the moment.

It would seem more reasonable for higher tier missions to be specific to PvP games, and maybe even not map restricted, so that it's not so much about just completing them, which is honestly the way it feels to me right now. Sure, you get the players who can't afford more than a few games in a day, so maybe what Riot should be looking at is a middle ground between "grind-able in Coop" and "unachievable for less active players".

The mission system certainly has a way to go before it will reach it's potential, so hopefully Riot will catch on to the things that are making it feel more like a grind than "achievements" within the next few iterations.

I agree.

'Achievements' is exactly right. Something that gives you a sense of accomplishment, but not something that make you skew your gameplay too much_ (e.g. we don't want people AFK farming for 40 minutes)_.

You're right, the missions are good, but they have a ways to go, I'm sure like you say, Riot will catch on.

I dunno, i think ashe coulda tried harder

Plus its better to have "win game" missions than "get 20 kills in 1 game" missions, people try harder to win instead of just pissing everyone off by stealing kills and not offering anything to their team

Yea, I was meaning myself and my friend. 
We were trying to win, but the rest of the team wasn't as keen on the idea. Taric was alright though. It's not their fault, they just had bad games, but its a shame that the missions punish us for other people's mistakes.

I definitely agree, you cant have ridiculous kill counts for missions, support and tank mains just wouldnt be able to compete with assassins and adcs.

But I think missions could be more along the lines of: Get 10 kills (over X number of games) as a mage, or as a fighter. That was anyone can participate, and it's not like you are being forced to play a specific champ. _(if they don't own either a mage or a fighter, I seriously question their commitment to the game)._

Even a support main can go a mage for a game or two without being completely offended, its not a huge ask. hell most mages can 'support' anyway.
But having to play assassins and mages move people out of their comfort zone, which riot doesnt want to do.

I agree that playing a specific champion might put someone out of their comfort zone. 
E.g. having to purchase and play Riven or Yasuo, just to complete missions.

But having to play 1 game as any champion from a specific class. Is not much of an ask.

All classify as mages. Thats roughly 1/3rd of all champions.
Asking someone to play 1 game as any of those champs is not a big ask at all.
Infact, if you didn't own or play any of those champions, I seriously question your dedication to the game.
There is a champ from literally every role in there that also counts as a mage.

Especially seeming as _(in theory)_ everyone is supposed to be able to play any role before starting ranked.

So I don't think there would be a huge problem with people being out of their comfort zones.
Even if there was, just make the mission to get kills or assists on X number of mages, or fighters etc.

The play with x champ on team is fine, but i do agree that you need to play x champ yourself is pushing it a little. Though as i did say, some people might absolutely despise the assassin role and will get cancer from playing that role, which really pushes them out of comfort zones. As i said before, missions that are "play with x class on your team" might be more viable, as this allows people to finish missions without being forced into something they dont like.

If you have a support main, despises assassins (thus plays janna because support main who hates assassins), and only play ranked, it becomes unlikely that person will ever finish the mission. As such games that simply require your team to have x variable met are more viable and enjoyable for the whole family. 

Back to the "Play x champ", that might cause more problems in the fact mains could be denied their champions because everyone wants to play that champ to finish the mission. EG, the mission where you needed to play a game as kayn yourself was quite difficult for many as he was picked by someone else nearly every game, but if it is closer to "Have a kayn on your team for 5 games", its more plausible and likely to happen.  Think of it as a waterbed versus a spring bed, one is awkward and comes with many mixed reviews, the other is a solid statement anyone can be satisfied with (heh comfort zones... beds... im funny).
